Package io.nem.symbol.sdk.model.transaction

Class TransactionFactory<T extends Transaction>

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.nem.symbol.sdk.model.transaction.TransactionFactory<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the transaction class an instance of this factory builds.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AccountAddressRestrictionTransactionFactory, AccountKeyLinkTransactionFactory, AccountMosaicRestrictionTransactionFactory, AccountOperationRestrictionTransactionFactory, AddressAliasTransactionFactory, AggregateTransactionFactory, HashLockTransactionFactory, MetadataTransactionFactory, MosaicAddressRestrictionTransactionFactory, MosaicAliasTransactionFactory, MosaicDefinitionTransactionFactory, MosaicGlobalRestrictionTransactionFactory, MosaicSupplyChangeTransactionFactory, MultisigAccountModificationTransactionFactory, NamespaceRegistrationTransactionFactory, NodeKeyLinkTransactionFactory, SecretLockTransactionFactory, SecretProofTransactionFactory, TransferTransactionFactory, VotingKeyLinkTransactionFactory, VrfKeyLinkTransactionFactory
    public abstract class TransactionFactory<T extends Transaction>
extends java.lang.Object
    The transaction factories allow you to create instances of transactions.

    The benefits of using a factory instead of a constructor:

    • Transactions can be immutable
    • Better support for default values like deadline and max fee
    • Better extensibility, fields can be added to Transaction without affecting the subclasses. It's not necessary to change subclasses constructors.
    • Massive constructors are not necessary in the Transaction subclasses
    • Mappers are easier to implement as top level mappers can set the top level transaction attributes via the factories without affecting the mapper subclasses

    When a new transaction type is added, a new extension of this factory should be added too.
